@danshipper -- I read your piece about Roam, and I've been curious about the product since I heard people loving the linking it has. I played around with the ideas in my own product, Drummer -- and came to the same conclusion you did.

I went further and implemented a search facility and loaded in about a decade worth of blog posts to it. I love it. Google's search has been degrading for years, but it was never as good as my dedicated search. Here's an example search. [link]

I've been working on outliners for a long time, and I like the direction #toolsforthought has been pulling me. 

I think search is the answer. You shouldn't have to plan in advance for what will be easily findable in the future. You very often have no idea what will be important.

In Frontier we have two verbs that can be used to normalize the formatting of XML files. They are:

xml.compile (xmltext) returns xstruct

xml.decompile (xstruct) returns xmltext

Is there the equivalent in Node.js?

### I am tweeting via RSS

This is a thread that will turn into a longish element in my RSS feed of tweets.

Somewhere in the middle of this thread I will provide the URL of the feed.
I'm using GitHub to store the RSS feed, because GitHub has a bunch of very sophisticated notification services that I think might add to the RSS experience.
It might even make the RSS world-of-tweets perform at the scale of [link]? Certainly better than any server I could deploy. ;-)
RSS definitely could use another look given the reality of  server cost and performance of 2022. Last time we did this work was maybe 15 years ago?

### Another test

I have the feed working, I think.

This will test that. 

If it works, I will see this as a titled item in my RSS reader. The title will be "Another test".

Each of the paragraphs will be enclosed in an HTML paragraph element.

Here goes nothing! 🙏🏽
And this is what that tweet looks like in the feed. Check it out -- it has a title! That's new. [link]

### Markdown document titles

I'm pretty sure Markdown does not have the concept of the title of a document.

But titles are important. RSS has the concept of a title because many blog posts have titles.

### cont'd

Tweets don't have titles, but they could.

And that would make the match betw Twitter and RSS work, where the last time it was tried it didn't.

I believe this was the reason it didn't work.

### cont'd

Also I think I just figured out how to hook up threads to RSS feed items that are longer than 280 chars.

Why didn't I figure this out sooner?

February 12

### The Sims as a metaverse

I used to pour days, even weeks into The Sims.

At one point I went cold turkey, gave it up, it was too much of a time sink.

But it's a metaverse, way more interesting than anything I've seen from Zuck.

Maybe it's time for a revival.

### An idea

What if we put Markdown in tweets, like this ⬆︎

Now my tweet has a title, and can look good in all RSS readers even those that require titles.

Now that there are 280-character tweets it makes more sense than when the limit was 140.
@brunomiguel @Apple That’s why I said @apple did it to me.

Customer support people who start “I understand your frustration…” are playing an nasty game called gaslighting. @apple  just did it to me. I never said I was frustrated. Mainly I want to be treated as a customer.
@MarkAStout @Apple That’s right.
@vnoel The process is built into Drummer, my latest outliner.
@dermotcasey This has already happened once. Apple sent another phone via UPS.

This is what Apple says when UPS has lost a $1300 phone I bought from Apple. Two parts.

“We’re sorry to hear your delivery is stalled. Unfortunately, once in the hands of UPS, Apple no longer has control.
“You will need to reach out to UPS and see if they can keep it at the depot and allow you to pick it up, or if they have any other options to help you get your device faster.”

My response.

“Your job is to deliver a phone to me. I paid you the money, not UPS.“

I gave them my money 16 days ago.

I fixed a bug. There's an encoding mismatch between text coming from Twitter through its API, which is encoded in UTF-8, and text in OPML files which is encoded in ISO-8859-1. In outlines that *only* contain tweets the fix is simple. [link]

There's a chain of beating hearts connecting back in time from you to a fish that crawled onto land, one of your many ancestors (assuming you believe in evolution, I guess).

In a new readme I just wrote:

"The software I make is targeted to one goal, to build interop between people."

Why do we care about interop in software? 

Mostly because it facilitates interop between people.

I've used the term "working together" more than 100 times on my blog. [link] I'm kind of gobsmacked by that. Maybe the title of my memoir should be Pissing Into The Wind While Trying To Work Together. There must be a shorter way to say that. ;-)
The number of times "gobsmacked" has appeared on my blog? [link] Zero. 0. Nada. Never happened. I think I'll use it in a post right now.
There Is Nothing Normal about One Million People Dead from COVID. [link]

I have a free service that keeps an archive of your tweets in machine-readable form on GitHub. [link] You don't have to install any software. It's all done on my server, which I'm running as part of a bootstrap. You can help by signing up.

As I do a review of this [link], I see all kinds of ways to improve and extend it. This is what happens when you put down a project for a month and come back to it with a fresh perspective. I think I'm going to spend a few days on this now. ;-)

BTW, the goal of the bootstrap:

Your tweets flowing through any outliner.

And from there where ever they go.

Public documents and private ones. 

To make Twitter a useful tool for ideation and organization. Individual projects and group projects.

And of course publishing.
We never had a connector like Twitter in the early days of outlining. I wanted it. Desperately. Now we have it.

More thoughts about the Beatles and their breakup.

None of the individual Beatles did better work after the breakup. They were unique, and as individuals had moments of greatness, but they had something that almost no one ever gets, a chance to be part of something great.
In software, you can try to team up with someone as good as you are, or just try to lead a team of people who do your work. I’ve always wanted the former, but pretty sure I never got it.

It would be like doing a product with Ward Cunningham as peers. Or John Borthwick, Mitch Kapor, Ray Ozzie, even Philippe Kahn. 

Some of the people I wish I had done products with. 

Hope I’m not embarrassing anyone. 😀
In sports, esp basketball they try to put together super teams, but they never seem to work. But look at the Warriors for an example of one that happened. They are kind of like the Beatles.

Mozart didn’t get to be a Beatle, or Beethoven, Bach. What if they had found a peer and worked out a collaboration?

Hemingway didn’t have a band either.

Just some random thoughts. This has been on my mind my whole career but has been coming into focus lately.

I feel strongly that packages that want to tie things together should be written in straight JavaScript, that's why I chose that as my development platform many years ago. Actually I'd prefer if we stuck to the JS we were using in 2013.
This is connected to my mission as a developer. I’m not trying to impress anyone. These days my product is interop. I’d like that to be my legacy. [link]

This is an important point. There was a big unforeseen cost in FB usurping the web and feeding nothing back. They could have peered with blogs, allowed two-way transit of open feeds in and out, and then had no responsibility for what appeared on FB. [link]

Interesting piece about Spotify. Of course they're not a music company. That's not a bad thing imho. But I might think it was if I was a musician. This is what the net did. Ek and Spotify are just opportunists. And Zuck and Facebook. [link]
It's kind of obvious Spotify wanted to own podcasting. Now, after Rogan, I wonder if they still want to own it.
It also seems obvious if they continue down this path, they're going to end up like Facebook, with a new name, and trying to be part of something vague that isn't Spotify.

And they're obviously lying when they say they value Rogan's right to free speech. Instead they're  desperately trying to preserve their $100 million investment. Better idea -- cut their losses, stop trying to own podcasting, while Spotify is still a decent name.

Facebook made the same mistake Spotify is making. They should have peered with the blogging world, and absolved itself of regulating speech. Instead they tried to dominate, and their brand became synonymous with all the abuse they imported from the web.
Ek says he won't "silence" Rogan. But in no way does he have the power to silence anyone. If he were to stop carrying Rogan on his network, Rogan would still have the entire open web to speak on.

Ek is really saying is he doesn't want to lose his $100 million. If he told this truth, obviously no one but his shareholders would sympathize. I think if he chose to lose the  money it would be worth it. If he proceeds down this path he's going to lose a lot more.

@dkiesow BTW I really like that you and others are willing to let me speak about podcasting. It's been so weird, my thoughts about podcasting are considered irrelevant by the analysts. But they don't get the value of having a standard that isn't owned by a platform.

@dkiesow It's as if this stupid "Web3" thing has a point when they say all the content is locked up in Facebook's servers. Well it isn't. Podcasting is a very strong counter argument. Hopefully maybe the journalists will listen.

@KenSmith I think they're fed up with the company.

@dkiesow It's also false advertising. As if you said your car gets 350 miles per gallon when it gets 35.

Is there a nice open source JavaScript clone of Wordle? By nice I mean: 1. It covers all the functionality of the original. 2. The code is clearly written, not obfuscated, easy to build on. No amazing JS tricks, just straight boring code.

I'd like to add a simple back-end, to automatically save your history, publish an RSS feed. Easily integratable into a community. Back-end is open source Node app. 

I'll just operate a server a few Wordler friends. A labor of love like the original app.

interop is the answer to dominance by large companies. 

a perfect time to build a ring of interop now is around Wordle clones. 

the word of the day should be the same across all clones, and there should be a single place where users' history is stored.

what an incredible demo this would be. 

it might teach the journalists at the NYT and elsewhere of the power of open formats and opportunities to work together. 

and the tech is sufficiently simple to pull it off.

I'm sorry that the NYT bought Wordle. 

Part of its appeal was that it was a nice web app that had no scaling issues, written by a person who was happy not to be a billionaire, and everyone was loving it.

Now that it's attached to the NYT, there's an element of hate there too.

I thought maybe it would show the world that ordinary people who love their GF and wants to make something nice for her and decides to share it with the world and retains his human-ness -- that software can be fun and doesn't have to be this hot mess of greed.

BTW this is true, software *is* made by people, not icons, and I don't blame Mr Wordle for taking the money. I just hope he stays a nice person and doesn't get caught up in being more than a human being.

I read in the NYT this morning that inflation is up and people are mad. 

I didn't read the article, I'm too scared, because they always make things sound terrible for Biden, when in truth, inflation is the result of a strong economy.

If you want inflation to flatten or go down, just start a recession and inflation will go down. 

Raise interest rates. Your savings will go up in value, and your adjustable rate mortgage will go up too.

There are few silver bullets in economics.
